Thanks for fun memories. Time to move on.

posts.com:
Dear Ash Ketchup.

20 years ago I was a kid, like you.

I watched your show while eating my cereal every morning.

I watched for two seasons, during the height of Pokemania.

We traded pokemon cards in the schoolyards, but none of us knew how to play.
Instead we just flipped them and whoever got face up won.
We discussed every episode.
We traded and argued.

We played the first two generation games.
We played your game, Pokemon Yellow.

I will never forget these memories. This is what made me love Pokemon.

Goodbye Ash,
now we grow old
and fade into obscurity.

I'm glad he's at least getting sent out on a high note.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52680150
>it's a giant nothingburger rooted in knee jerk nostalgia.
The nostalgia part is absolutely correct, but it's kind of a big deal aside from that as well. Regardless of what waifufags think, Ash and Pikachu are the most recognizable faces in the entire IP. While I don't think Pikachu is getting shunted from the merch anytime soon, it's still a pretty big shakeup. It's been 25 fucking years with the same 2 characters, why now? Why not earlier? It'd be like hearing the Simpsons is ending. Sure, it's been decades since it's been good, but people just got used to it always being there in the background. So when it finally gets retired it comes across as a shock.

On the point of Nostalgia, I think the news is hitting people harder than you might think because for many people, they simply aged out of the games/anime. They left on their own volition with the knowledge that this character would continue on without them in some ethereal sense. But now that Ash is finally retiring "for realzies" this time, those people have to confront the fact that something they were familiar with now unmistakably gone. Like growing apart from a childhood friend you were on good terms with, then learning years later that they died or became a drug addict or what have you. Sure you hadn't seen them in years, but it's still painful to hear.

It was fun while it lasted, though.

posts.com:
>J is ruthless, relentless, and cruel, willing to do anything to capture Pokémon for her clients, up to and including injuring innocent people or Pokémon. In her debut episode, she chose to drop some of her henchmen to their potential deaths without hesitation or remorse, emphasizing her intensely independent, sociopathic, greedy, and callous nature. She has no honor, decency, or regard for any form of life - the only thing that matters to her is money. She is one of the very few characters (including the Iron-Masked Marauder, Dr. Yung, Grings Kodai, and Alva) in the anime who is purely evil.

J is also highly pragmatic. She is reluctant to harm Pokémon that she is trying to capture - as they would be less valuable to her clients - and she will forgo direct combat in favor of sneak attacks and mass destruction if the opportunity presents itself. This contributes to her high threat level in the series. However, she also tends to underestimate her opponents when on the verge of victory, which often leads to her defeat and ultimately ensures her (seemingly) final downfall.

Out of all of the characters that encountered her, she has a dislike for Ash the most as evidenced when he kept on interfering with her job and the fact that most of the encounters had Ash nearly killed or severely injured had it not been for the unlikely intervention of his friends and Pokémon, and other characters supporting the protagonists.

Quoted from bulbapedia.

>>52691487
Yeah that's exactly why it's a lame cop-out.
"Well MY one is special because....IT JUST IS OKAY!!!"
You shouldn't teach kids that everything they personally make, do or participate in is "special" by virtue of them doing it; that is a recipe for narcissism.
There was a study done not that long ago about how people who don't know how to fight manage to stay confident walking around a city at night - almost everyone said something to the effect of;
>well I just have a secret berserk mode where I'll bite and gouge eyes so I'll be fine
...Turns out that's not a reliable strategy at all if you're up against someone who is strong or trained or has allies.
My point is that "I'm special" is not a good philosophy; we should teach kids to build something and grow strong, not just be the best from day one like the invincible bullshit Pikachu.

SM had two character designers, Satoshi Nakano who designed Ash, his mom, Oak, TR and Misty/Brock, and Shuhei Yasuda who designed everyone else. RB/GS were perfect I think, very local stories that you read or hear about while traveling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So yeah, I like the Gen 1 cards but there was a lot wrong with the game.

1. Horribly unbalanced. The game was so unbalanced the best strategy was going with mid HP, low Attack mons and cycling your deck to get anything you want. You want an example, try the TCG for Gameboy. It's stupid easy to win once you have enough cards to do the Haymaker. Other archetypes like Energy Tans and Rainmaker really just weren't as successful.
2. For whatever reason the Gym series is almost entirely illustrated by Ken Sugimori, and it feels strange, honestly. On the one hand we got some new art that wasn't seen anywhere else, but on the other hand could you imagine if we'd gotten some badass later artists like Miki Tanaka, Tomokazu Komiya, or other extant artists like Tomoaki Imakuni had been doing card art for the set? I don't think it was a money thing either; I think they were afraid of diverging from the established style, a sin they'd come to repeat later on.
3. The US was often plagued by supply shortages. I recall specifically we never got first edition products for: Base Set, Fossil, Gym Heroes, Neo Discovery, Neo Revelation, or Neo Destiny where I lived. Yet, probably 70% of my Team Rocket cards are First Edition. I guess I got lucky that's a good set.
4. Official products were... lacking. Theme decks were 40% energy cards, you got one rare. I think that was mostly just WotC. Though i think they could have made some better products if they had a longer leash.

That said I loved the cosmo galaxy foil, miss it, wish they'd use it again. Loved the large Yellow borders, the spiky evolution boxes, and the aesthetic.

>>52697952
Whilst Rock/Fighting/Flying don’t resist themselves, they are the only other totally balanced triangle.

>Each is SE on the one before it (Rock < Fighting < Flying)
>Each is resisted by the one after it (Rock > Fighting > Flying)
>Each has the same self-target relation (neutral damage)

Compare this to Fighting/Dark/Psychic, where Dark < Psychic results in an immunity and 2/3 resists themselves - or Fighting/Fairy/Steel, where only Steel resists itself.

posts.com:
>>52695744
>>52695721
1x Fuecoco
1x Skeledirge
2x Quaxly
4x Sprigatito
2x Charmander
1x Gengar

I do kind of respect the starter surprise trades even if I've already got them all. They don't show up in raids, and they always make the day for people who don't already have them.
There is an in-game Haunter trade that evolves into Gengar. And they show up in raids. But at least it's a pokemon you can't evolve by yourself.
That Skeledirge was kind of odd though. Level 39. It did spawn from an egg so it wasn't their actual starter, but they did level it up and evolve it before surprise trading it. Kind of rare I think even if it's no better than simply receiving a Fuecoco.

Now I was going to shit on this trade session for giving me zero version exclusives of any kind. But truth is, that the 36th oof these 40 trades actually gave me a Scream Tail. A Scarlet Paradox mon that's not in my version, doesn't appear in raids, and that I didn't have.
In total that Scream Tail would have been my 67th surprise trade. But I finally surprise traded with someone else trading their version's paradox pokemon.

I will however still shit on these trades and these players for how not a single one of these trades. ZERO of them. Came with a Held Item.
People really don't give a shit. 71 trades and not a single Held Item of any kind.

Overall I am satisfied because I actually got a Scream Tail. But I am still disappointed in people for the complete lack of Held Items.
But Surprise Trades are kind of exciting. I kind of thought I'd never actually get a Scream Tail through Surprise Trades.
And separate to the Surprise Trades, I found a shiny Iron Valiant while catching Paradox pokemon in Area Zero. So I am very happy. Catching the stragglers while I was there was alright. And the 40 Malicious Armors I got from like a single Sinistea mass outbreak coupled with an item drop sandwich.
And hopefully a lot of the players appreciated my Violet Paradox pokemon and Malicious Armors.

>>52673685
The rebellion idea didn't stem from things like the OP. Takeshi Shudo clearly didn't view Pokémon as people, for example he didn't want subtitles for the episode where the Pokémon are stranded because he thought it would be too humanizing and would strip away the aspect of Pokémon as separate creatures from humanity by anthropomorphizing them. At one point he mentions he didn't like writing tears into his scripts for Pokémon because animals don't cry although he recognizes that by necessity Pokémon have to be anthropomorphized to some degree.

In Shudo's framework he saw the relationship between humans and Pokémon as humans taming nature because of the battle and capture aspect, not because Pokémon were treated as pets. He at one points mentions that Pokémon is a series about capturing and enslaving animals to fight on the behalf of humans. Indeed the Dingglet episode of the anime was made to foreshadow when nature doesn't bend to humanity's whims.

>>52680531
To put it simply because that's not what Pokémon is. Pokémon as a series draws heavily from Satoshi Tajiri childhood which was spent exploring a creek and collecting all manners of creatures, his biography makes it clear he collected more than bugs, and once that connection to nature was lost when he attended middle school it left a big impression on him. Reading his biography he makes it very clear his childhood was one of the inspirations, and would later become the biggest influence, for Pokémon.

Pokémon are not conceptualized to be human-adjacent creatures like dwarves or elves, Tajiri makes it very clear that he sees Pokémon as pets, he sees them as the animals he collected, took care and interacted with from his childhood. The pet aspect has been there from the get go, a book released in 1995 has Tajiri calling Pokémon kaiju-like pets, the 1996 pokedec mentions how Pokémon make better pets than cats and dogs. Further reading such as Shudo saying it was decided that they, and they most likely refers to the people working on the anime possibly including Tajiri, would see the relation between humans and Pokémon in the same way as non-human creatures and humans in the real world, that is creatures that are part of the natural world. This is blatantly said by the Pokémon company themselves in the 2010 guide.

Simply put it doesn't happen because that's not what Pokémon are and never will be. Pokémon knows what it wants Pokémon to be and how to construct them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52683885
Here are the panels clearly showing how much of an impact it had towards the idea of Pokémon. Simply put there is no aliens, rodents or spirits but only Pokémon. The series even makes it clear that there are no actual spirits, only Pokémon that exhibit spirit like powers. The series doesn't make these sorts of distinctions you are suggesting because that's not part of Pokémon vision. Pokémon conceptualizes the fantastical into the natural, it sees fantasty fictional beings conceptualized as being closer to cute little critters more than anything else. This is why Pokémon eat dog food, or as in HGSS bark and chew on shoes, or exhibit zoomies just like real cats and dogs do. Because that is Tajiri's vision of Pokémon and a vision the series continues to uphold to this very day. Even Takeshi Shudo didn't make those distinctions, he very much saw all the original 151 Pokémon as critters, in his blog he describes Pokémon as a group of animals arranged from familiar *objects* and creatures. It’s clear he recognized that design inspiration was wide but their conceptualization in-context meant that they were cute little critters.

When it comes to that aspect of the Pokemon franchise, no. They're just doing what they've been saying from the very start. Everything here relates to the early development of Pokemon, the 4chan post is a translation of the 1996 Pokedex released in Japan only, the Dr. Lava page is from 1995, and the one about whipping is from an early book written by one of GameFreak's developers. Shudo's quote is about how the anime staff decided to think the relationship between humans and Pokemon as and of course the games told you the same thing in the first instances of the games.

With this in mind Pokemon being portrayed that way falls in line with what they've been saying all this time. Indeed Pokemon have been conceptualized as these creatures being like cats and dogs since the start, and that's the reason they act and are treated certain ways in the anime and games. You can fault gamefreak for being lazy in some areas but this isn't one of them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Farigiraf's an absolute beast in doubles Trick Room strategies.

120/70/70 defenses + a solid defensive typing (Normal/Psychic) gives it only two weaknesses and few ways to exploit them. Bug and Dark are fairly relevant offensive typings, but also typings that lack high-damage moves (outside of Megahorn, which no one uses).

Very few Pokemon can remove a Farigiraf from the field without some sort of set-up or assistance. Modest Torkoal using Heat Wave in the sun is a solid 2HKO (100% Eruption just barely manages to get the 1HKO).

While it's on the field, Farigiraf has a crazy amount of support utility. It can outright disable an opponent's Priority moves. It's got access to double screens. It can Helping Hand its ally's moves. It's got Trick Room - turning its own mediocre speed into an advantage and enables entire team strategies. It's also one of the few pokemon with access to Ally Switch.

Offensively, it also has enough threats between access to Foul Play/Low Kick/Grass Knot (which scale based off of opponents) and its base 110 SpAtk + access to Psychic/Psyshock/Future Sight/Hyper Voice STABS + coverage moves like Dazzling Gleam, Energy Ball, Shadow Ball, and Thunderbolt. Base 90 Atk even makes physical choices not completely unviable, with additional access to Earthquake as another option.

A typical moveset for it will almost be guaranteed to include Trick Room and Hyper Voice, but its sheer variety as a potential offensive threat and as a supporter for another offensive mon make it extremely difficult to determine what an opposing Farigiraf is about to do to your own team.

Didn't we used to say that the archetypes for modern starters were Cool, Tough and Feminine? I feel like that's the only three categories you need to organize most of the Pokémon these days. Yeah, there are definitely cute Pokémon that are not feminine and there are definitely weird Pokémon or goofy Pokémon that aren't necessarily cool or tough. But I think in general they all fit into those three broad categories of who they would appeal to, not necessarily their design philosophy. It is weird though being as old as I am and being a fan for this long and seeing how much more refined they have become with how the design Pokémon. Generations 1 and 2 just felt like a lot of blobs and generic RPG monsters. Then we started getting more extreme looking monsters, and now we've landed at having a smorgasbord of completely marketable characters rather than monsters all based on real life things. Definitely noticeable as a trend over the 25+ years

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52699607
Once you beat Whitney, the region really opens up, and you can explore a large section of the region before having to commit to fighting Morty, and you have a choice of the gyms beyond that. Chuck, Pryce, and Jasmine are all in a very similar level range, and not with great movesets either. A well-rounded team shouldn't have any trouble.
The biggest challenge is Red, and part of that is simply due to the fact that he's vastly higher level than everyone else, so getting a team raised up for him could take a while.

Comparing that to other early entries like Red/Blue, which has more exploitable AI, but also gives the 6th gym leader a level 43 Alakazam compared to Jasmine's level 35 Steelix. Or just the teams of the respective rivals where, again, Blue has a Alakazam level 50 Alakazam before you challenge the league, while Silver still only has a level 35 Kadabra at victory road.
HGSS improves this mostly with things like movesets and held berries for gym aces, though also with some parts of the curve, like how Pryce's team is 3 levels higher across the board. Not exactly groundbreaking, but a marked improvement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52699739
Yeah, I understand that they're making the games easier. I just found myself being actually surprised at the level differences between my team and some of the bosses throughout the game. I never got that feeling in any of the other games in the E tier, other than maybe Mustard's battle in SWSH.
I don't know how much that has to do with how I did my playthrough, though, since I don't really remember fighting too many trainers, so maybe I was more underleveled than average.
Still, the first Nemona fight, the Great Tusk titan, Eri, Arven, Director Clavell, the AI - all gave me more of a run for my money than any other game in E tier. That's why I'd put it up in D at the very least.

So... what exactly happens when you catch pokemon with pokeballs? Do they get brainwashed into obeying you? Are they naturally hardwired to accept whoever captures them as their master? Or do they accept capture because they realize that it'd probably lead to a more comfortable existence than living in the wild?
I've heard of the "all pokemon are naturally attracted to humans and want to serve them" argument, but it falls flat on its ass considering the likes of Hatterene, Froslass and tons of ghost types have no qualms about murdering people. So... what is it?
This question goes for all pokemon media - mainline games, spin-offs, anime, manga, whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52699511
>Or do they accept capture because they realize that it'd probably lead to a more comfortable existence than living in the wild?
I would assume it's mostly this, with a hint of brainwashing. Canonically the capturing invokes a fear response, which is what makes the Pokemon shrink. Presumably the comfort and security of the Poke Ball after that response plays a key role in the Pokemon's connection to the trainer, which is why you can't change balls. Beyond that however, I feel like it's mostly a matter of comfort, security, and convenience. Most Pokemon have an inherent lust for battle that a trainer conveniently facilitates.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Pokemon only accept capture once they want to be captured except for Master Balls. Game mechanics mess with that but it's the intention. Like I doubt that Pokemon will really respect you more for poisoning them, and stuff like quick balls have no real reason to convince Pokemon faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52699549
Redpill me on shrinking. Is that an official thing or just a persistent headcanon? It certainly doesn't seem to be a thing in the anime for all it's worth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52699645
Not that anon but it's an official thing that was established way back in like 1996 or so in some tie-in book that dumps a lot a lore about then-current Gen 1 canon. Apparently it's the kind of thing that among Japanese fans was an "everyone knows this" deal, going by the way people on that side reacted to western fans freaking out about it, but like implied, wasn't well-known for literal decades seemingly like anywhere else. Mainly because like you said, stuff like the anime and even some of the games was either inconsistent with depicting it or straight-up didn't depict it at all.

Like yeah, some people assumed they get shrunk in a way when captured, but assumed it was a technology thing done by the Poke Ball and not an inherent biological instinctive reaction of the Pokemon themselves, which has only started to get stated explictly comparatively recently, as in within dialogue, in mainline games.

It's kind of stupid and weird and honestly if I'd known years ago that capturing Pokemon wasn't "get Pokemon with magic technology" but instead like "let's force Pokemon to involuntarily display this weird reflex action usually only displayed in life-threatening for ease of capture" I'm positive it would've just creeped me out as a kid and I wouldn't have gotten into this shit in the first place, but that's how it is I GUESS

I'm not a fan of it honestly but mostly because I think it could've been shown better visually in various media (weird that the anime crew for example was allowed to so obviously do "they're converted to energy/data" if them shrinking is such a major thing in the games it's based on) or at least talked about more in-game, but at this point yeah obviously it's the actual intention.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Seems to be some kind of Japanese honour thing. In loads of JP media especially video games and shonen, the protagonist will fight their villain, and when defeated, the villain will have a change of heart or give up on their evil goals due to their respect for the strength of their opponent and their beliefs. Pokemon battling with Trainers is treated more like sparring or martial arts competitions, especially where Fighting types are concerned. A defeated wild Pokemon comes to understand and respect the Trainer, willingly trains under their guidance to improve their skills, and follows the Trainer in their goals. “There are no evil Pokemon, only bad Trainers” as an ideology matches this, as the Pokemon respect the strength of their Trainers’ beliefs, regardless of the moral intent. Its well demonstrated that if an inexperienced Trainer catches a Pokemon that believes itself to be superior, the Pokemon has the freedom to disobey, refuse to leave their ball, refuse to return to their ball, refuse to start fighting, refuse to stop fighting, etc. There’s no brainwashing involved, just the ‘community spirit’ of Japanese culture in a simplified child media form of becoming friends with your partner mon.

>>52680766
That's a weird translation thing. It wasn't translated WRONG, exactly. The term used in Japanese is ともだち記念日. The "記念日" is a term that's usually used for anniversaries, but it's also used for some holidays. So it's not entirely clear whether it's saying "our friendship anniversary" or "Friendship Day". 4kids went with the more obvious translation.

But there's some extra context to it. The short's ending song in Japan is also called "もだち記念日" and the lyrics give a bit more insight into what it means. Basically, the song is about reminiscing about the day you met someone. Then it caps off with something to the effect of "Someone, somewhere is out there meeting their future best friend today, so that makes today Friendship Day/a Friendship Anniversary! So let's all celebrate it!"

So basically ともだち記念日 is just any day you choose to celebrate your best friend, since every day is one.

posts.com:
Since we know for certain at least one of these will be coming in 2024/25, let's discuss our thoughts and ideas and any concerns we may have for the upcoming Johto remakes.

My main concern is that we'll get BDSP-style remakes in the style of GSC, with nothing taken from HGSS. That is of course the worst case scenario. The second worst case scenario is that it's a BDSP-style remake of HGSS with nothing changed, so the 7th Gym Leader will still be using a level 30 Seel and Blackthorn City will still be a shithole filled with mud huts.

Personally, if I were in charge of the Johto remakes, I'd do a re-imagining of the region in full 3D, so the routes are wider and more open and the houses in cities aren't just facing one direction anymore, it'd include everything from HGSS, and all the NPC teams would be completely reworked. The closest example I can find to what my perfect Johto remake would be like is millenniumloop's 3D Johto videos: https://youtu.be/nKUqyLI1r0U

>>52690948

>>52695419
6/10, strips the "low-brow" street artist look too much. Keep the "hoodie" pattern as fur coloring with the bulges "frayed" into fur tufts, maybe SLIGHTLY larger eyes or "mascara" for the effect to keep "The Fuck Is With Those Eyes?!" energy.

>>52696351
Actually, Pokémon is one of the few game series that *doesn't* cheat percentage chances.

Most games roll d% twice and average the results, which exaggerates common events to be more common and rare events to be more rare. I.e. 50-50 odds are still 50-50, but if an event claims to be 1-in-100 then it's actually 1-in-10,000.

Those other games where "80% accuracy" seemed reliable? That's because under the hood it was actually something like 97% accuracy.

Wormadam-G looks remarkably like a slice of pizza—more so than any other Pokemon. This means that it could be a tasty snack for your teammates once they get weakened and need more energy. However, it is still terrible at being a pizza, as it is a "sandy" forme, so it will taste worse than the bitter feeling of defeat that you get after losing when you use this Pokemon. It should be noted that the bagworm is the lightest fully evolved Pokemon (and the only pizza) that learns Fissure. -snip-
Margherita
Wormadam-Sandy @ Leftovers
Ability: Anticipation
EVs: 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def
Adamant Nature
- Stealth Rock
- Earthquake
- Rock Blast
- Sucker Punch
Moves
Does this set look familiar? Yes, that is because Golem can do the exact same thing but not suck completely. If you need a more detailed summary of the moves you should go to the Golem analysis, as you might be able to get some use out of the Pokemon slot.
Set Details
Maximum Attack investment and an Adamant nature let Wormadam-G actually do some damage, and the HP EVs allow it to survive a hit from quite a few physical attackers. Leftovers provides some passive recovery, which Wormadam-G otherwise lacks.
Usage Tips
When it's not out massacring opposing teams, Wormadam-G should just try to set up Stealth Rock. You will be lucky if it ends up doing anything other than maybe dealing some chip damage with Sucker Punch or possibly Rock Blasting an obvious Pelipper switch-in. To ensure that Wormadam-G gets up Stealth Rock, try to switch it into a weak physical attacker. -snip-
Team Options
lol, lmao
Other Options
You can add pepperoni with Bug Bite as a Bug-type STAB move to hit Grass-types, but that is still weak. A Hawaiian Pizza set with Choice Band can make Wormadam-G hit somewhat hard, but you lose the utility of Stealth Rock. Lastly, you can use a Veggie Supreme set, which is a defensive set with Toxic; this utilizes Wormadam-G's Defense, its only good stat, but it is almost always just setup fodder.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52690343
Because people would put themselves on Set mode accidentally, find out that they're no longer able to switch out Pokemon when they beat a trainer's mon in battle, and then have no clue how to undo whatever they did.

The only real mechanical benefit in keeping Set mode was that it'd remove a single dialogue prompt before a trainer sends out their next Pokemon. Beyond that, Set mode just served as a 'make the game slightly more challenging' button for competitive enthusiasts. And I say this as someone who actually likes Set mode.

The existence of Set mode until this point was a trade-off between appeasing people like me who want to complete battles as quickly as possible and steamroll with my overpowered team, and appeasing the actual target demographic (literal children) who are more than capable of accidentally scrolling through a menu, toggling a bunch of settings one way or another, then don't know why they suddenly can't switch out their Quaxly when an NPC trainer sends out their Pikachu on the heels of a previous KO.

If a minor QoL improvement for optimizers and speedrunners is going to continue to provide a negative impact for the actual intended target audience of your product, why wouldn't you remove it?

>>52690656
The Johto League is the most weak and pathetic of any in the series, in part due to their low levels but there are more fundamental flaws too. The first gym leader's ace is a Level 9 Pidgeotto, the second one uses a Metapod and Kakuna. The fifth gym leader only uses two Pokémon, the seventh gym leader is weaker than the sixth. You don't fight a Level 40 Pokémon before the eight leader's ace or a Level 50 one before the Champion; the only trainers in the entire game with a Pokémon over Level 50 are Blue and Red. The "curve" plateaus at Lance, the entire region of Kanto afterward offers no increased challenge until you get the minor bump of Blue and spike at Red, and you'd need to do a ridiculous amount of grinding to put together a team of Level 70s to match his. Not that you'd really need to, his team is still easy even without the player's natural advantage from Badge Boosts.

OP is arguing that none of this matters because the remakes HGSS makes some effort to bump up Levels for a better experience, including boosting rematchable NPC trainers' final teams by over 20 levels across the board.
What they don't mention is that you can't rematch trainers at all until you defeat Team Rocket at the Radio Tower (after the 7th Gym), you can't get their third team until you beat the Champion, and you can't fight their fourth and final teams being showcased here until you get all 16 Badges. Also, you can only battle them once per day, and they're only available at a specific time of day on ONE day of the week. This ALSO applies to Gym Leader rematches in HGSS with the added bonus that you can't just get their number after beating them, you have to track them down at ANOTHER specific location, time and time of day first.

TL;DR if you want to grind in the Johto games there is no reason to engage with any of this shit because you can just rematch the E4 whenever you want as many times as you want for better money and EXP than any other trainer except Blue.

If the scaling was shit because of Kanto they would have actually continued the level curve into Kanto. Instead every trainer after Lance is weaker than Lance, except Blue and Red (Blaine's Rapidash also hits Level 50, but he only has three Pokémon).
They're all weaker than the Champion except the former Champions because that "makes sense," even though it's not good game design. Janine is the most clear example, she's significantly weaker than the other Kanto gym leaders because she's a rookie taking over for Koga. It's not a big deal in HGSS where that means she's "only" as strong as Lance but in GSC you're fighting a team of Level 30s (which is still better than all but one Johto gym).

>>52694586
The problem isn't just that it's easy, everything being so low-level makes some Pokémon basically impossible to use. You could pick up a Dratini in Goldenrod and be training it the entire game but it still won't be fully evolved by the time you beat the Elite Four and there are only two worthwhile trainers in the game after that.
Donphan doesn't learn Earthquake, its ONLY ground-type move, until Level 49, and it's far from the only Gen 2 mon with a shit movepool. Skarmory doesn't learn Steel Wing (its only STAB option besides Peck) until 49, Heracross doesn't learn Megahorn (its only STAB option besides Reversal) until 54, Togetic doesn't learn Double-Edge (its ONLY ATTACKING MOVE besides Metronome) until 38.

For the record, everyone's favorite games Black and White has very similar issues with a weak level curve and weak gym leaders (consistently just a few levels ahead of Johto's curve and capped at 3 Pokémon), on top of having many Pokémon who aren't usable until unreasonably high levels, but it gets far less criticism because its linear design makes for a much smoother curve and the postgame east half of Unova immediately gives you many trainers with Level 60+ Pokémon to fight.

The problem stems from the non-linear game design.

After beating Morty you can head west, which means fighting down to Olivine, fighting through the lighthouse, fighting over to Cianwood, fighting Chuck and then finally fighting Janine or you can head east, fight your way to Mahogany, fight up to the Lake of Rage, fight through the Rocket base with Lance, fight through the radio tower and all that Goldenrod shit, then fight Pryce. And of course you can go back and forth between the two.

It means there's a huge stretch of the game where every opponent you face is around level 30, +/-5, reaching a point where it is no longer challenging or rewarding. You just end up in a chain of endless battles watching your blue bar grow a few pixels at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52683229
Yeah, TMs are back to being single-use. But most of them are added to random respawning loot tables dotted all over the place, so you can pick up a few copies of Protect or whatever without trying to. And whenever you pick up a new TM, you get the ability to craft them at Pokemon centers using materials you get from beating Pokemon. It doesn't take much, there's an autobattle feature where you can just throw your lead Pokemon at Pokemon on the overworld and it'll instantly beat it based on the type and level difference, and materials are tied to the whole evolutionary line of a Pokemon instead of the individual species. So you don't have to worry about Raichu having a higher-value material than Pichu, it just has more of them.

I didn't like the idea of how TMs work in SV at first, but it's easily the best implementation of them to date. Most of the time you don't even need to worry about it, you can sell them when you need some extra cash, and the few times I actually had to do some detective work to find out where I could find materials for that perfect TM I needed were a nice diversion.

Let's go one by one.

>Magnezone
Horrible design and it's not different enough from Magneton to justify its existence. The only reason people don't use Magneton is because Magnezone otherwise they do the exact same thing.

>Lickilicky
I don't like the top of its head but I don't hate the mon itself. One of most forgettable Gen 1 mons gets an equally forgettable crossgen evo.

>Rhyperior
I understand why people think it's ugly but I like it a lot. It's also one of strongest ground physical attackers and Solid Rock let's him to win tradeoffs against Fighting types and Ground types while Rhydon gained Eviolite so it was a positive networth for both sides.

>Tangrowth
It just gets bigger. It's okay, I don't care about Tangela either though some people complain a lot because the loss of speed.

>Electivire/Magmortar
Everyone said everything that can be said about them

>Porygon-Z
It's a complete shuffle from Porygon more defense oriented line but its great and Dubious Disk lets obvious what they were going after with that.

>Togekiss
WHY TOGETIC LOST ITS HANDS. Overrated as fuck, Togetic just became fat and crippled.

>Ambipom
Mega Aipom... but it got a nose and a weird bang. Just remove those and he will be fine.

>Yanmega
Yanma becomes fucking evil, I like the design a lot. One of my favorite crossgen evos.

>Honchkrow
Birds evos that become completely different species are all shit and this is no exception

>Mismagius
Give her Misdreavus palette and it'll be great. IDK why they changed.

>Gliscor
He's the fucking Gliscor.

>Weavile
I like Sneasel more but Weavile it's okay if not TOO similar

>Mamoswine
Great and makes great sense with the Ancient Power evo.

>Gallade
He was initially more interesting than Gardevoir despite the worse abilities because he had double typing. Then Gardevoir gained Fairy type. I could get in more details about why I think Gallade become less interesting as the time did go on but his Mega looks sick so it was worth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Isn't there any Pokémon that you have some kind of connection with?

Typhlosion is my favourite because it was my first ever Pokémon and its design is perfect to me.

I will never forget booting up SoulSilver for the first time and choosing Cyndaquil as my first partner Pokémon. Seeing it walk behind me was so awesome. I vividly remember it evolving into Typhlosion halfway up Route 43 on the way to the Lake of Rage, and then dropping my DS and crying because it reset an hour or two of progress. But did I give up? No. I took my Typhlosion all the way to the Pokémon League and we beat Lance together. I don't know how, but we did it.

I'm so grateful that I started with the peak of Pokémon. What wonderful games HeartGold & SoulSilver were.

Inject - Shitpost - Circlejerk

This thread is for Hacks and/or Clones. Come in and get free stuff!

It is very legit. People will post here to try to tell you otherwise. Ignore them.

>No one has fulfilled my request yet? Why?
Injectors fulfill requests out of the goodness of their own hearts, and on their own time. Be patient.

Use PKHex to create .PK9 files to help Injectors quickly load in the pokemon you want. Follow the guide.

Wi-Fi General does not condone hacks, and asking for or offering a hack over there will result in a completely unnecessary shitstorm. Play the game however you want, but if you want injections/genned Pokémon, play here in a more friendly, less autistic environment.
